incident_updates.body: The issue with check scheduling has been resolved and checks are running normally.
We are currently investigating an issue with check scheduling.

incidents.name: Dashboard is stuck in a login loop

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
Our web application is not accessible due to a login error. We're currently investigating this issue.

incidents.name: Dashboard is stuck in a login loop

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
Our upstream provider fixed this issue, and we're monitoring the situation.
Our web application is not accessible due to a login error. We're currently investigating this issue.

A scheduled job saturated our database resources between 10:50 AM UTC to 11:03 AM UTC. During this timeframe :

- checks were not scheduled.
- alerts were not sent. 
- dashboard was not accessible.
- our public API was responding with 500 errors.

Affected components : 
- API
- Web Application
- Public Dashboards
- Check Scheduler
- Deployments
- Alerting

We quickly stopped the faulty job, and everything is operating normally.
A faulty deployment impaired the runner infrastructure between 06:15 (UTC) and 07:08 (UTC) which delayed a subset of check executions.
A fix has been deployed by our partner. Deployments should now be running as usual.
We are seeing degraded performance in our deployment triggers (Vercel) as a result of upstream provider.

A deployment introduced a bug where failing checks with the “_Double-check on failure_” feature enabled were not processed. This means we were not able to report check results and alert users during the incident only for failing checks with the _“Double-check on failure”_ feature enabled.

A fix has been deployed and we’re improving our monitoring around this part of our infrastructure.
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published a postmortem on our March 7th incident: https://stspg.io/fyk9thtqh6bk

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
We identified the culprit and rolled back a faulty deployment. We're now monitoring the situation.
We're seeing degraded performances in our system and are investigating it.
A fix has been deployed by our partner. Deployments should now be running as usual.
We are seeing degraded performance in our deployment triggers (Vercel) as a result of upstream provider.
This incident has been resolved.
The incident is resolved and we are monitoring the situation
We are continuing to monitor for any further issues.
Some of our backend services were temporarily degraded, causing some checks to not be scheduled on-time. We have identified the cause and are monitoring.

incidents.name: Intermittent connection failures to Checkly API

incident_updates.body: We got confirmation from our provider that the issue is resolved and we can see that everything is working as expected
We are seeing intermittent connection failures to api.checklyhq.com. We contacted our upstream provider and investigating the root cause.

From 17:10 until 17:22 UTC, there was an outage in our analytics database. During this time, checks on private locations were not run since Checkly Agents were unable to pull new jobs. This incident also caused errors when viewing the check overview page or public dashboards.

The incident is now resolved. We're currently working to prevent similar issues from occurring again in the future.
This incident has been resolved.
The faulty deployment is rolled back and checks are recovering. We're still monitoring the situation.
We noticed an increase of failed checks, we've identified the culprit and are rolling back the faulty deployment.

We noticed an increase of failed checks after a deployment during a time window of 30 minutes between 3:05 pm UTC to 3:35 pm UTC. The faulty deployment was quickly rolled back and checks are now running as usual.

incidents.name: Degradation alerts are not being sent

incident_updates.body:
If you relied on degraded notifications to troubleshoot your APIs, we let you down completely. A bug slipped through our code review and testing processes and broke sending degradation alerts since June 2021.

It took so long for us to notice because degraded alerts are only used by a small fraction of our customers. Sending notifications on degradation is turned off by default. In addition, testing for the absence of action is harder to track although we do that for almost all parts of our check running and alerting pipelines: just not this part, obviously.

What we are doing to prevent this in the future:

* We have expanded our own E2E testing to cover the case we missed here.
* We will extend our own monitoring of our alerting pipeline to watch for a lack of processing of degradation alert messages.

Checkly is a different company now than it was 17 months ago. We have invested into reliability, testing, monitoring and observability across the board with new people, processes and tooling. The risk of introducing a bug such as the one reported here is drastically lower today than it was then.

If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to reach out.

Thanks,    
Tim & the Checkly Team
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published a postmortem on our October 14th incident: https://stspg.io/772z44bw0djd

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved and a fix has been shipped to production. If you're still having any issues, don't hesitate to reach out to us!
We've identified the issue and are working on a solution now.

We noticed during an internal check that degradation alerts (transitions from PASSING to DEGRADED) are currently not being sent out.

We are currently investigating this issue and will keep you updated as soon as we know more.

Our alerting service had a bug that caused our SMS delivery quota to be exhausted instantly. Our monitoring alerted us 5 days later because of a related problem. A fix was deployed and we are improving our alerting and monitoring to make sure we prevent further outages.

incidents.name: A partial outage of the deployment processing pipeline

incident_updates.body: Between 2022-08-30 20:18 and 2022-08-31 05:00 UTC, our deployment processing pipeline experienced a partial outage, caused by a stale database connection. Some of the deployments from that period were not processed, and their data has been lost.

incidents.name: A minor disruption in check scheduling

incident_updates.body: Today, between 20:15 and 20:25 UTC, some checks with frequencies of 10 minutes or higher were not scheduled by our system. Other check runs from that period were delayed. The reason for this incident is a delay in a database credential rotation.
This incident has been resolved.
We are continuing to monitor for any further issues.

We have identified an increase in the time required to consume and resolve check results. This lead to check results potentially not being saved between 11:49 - 14:00 CEST. We have applied a fix and are monitoring it closely.

From July 12 14:11 UTC until July 13 7:20 UTC, an API error occurred which made it impossible to edit check group settings. This issue has now been resolved, and we will improve our processes to avoid similar issues in the future.

incidents.name: Check failure with websites using casalemedia

incident_updates.body: A fix was released regarding this issue, our parsing is now more forgiving and will allow invalid urls to be parsed without causing any side effects. The faulty request, prefixed by "Invalid URL:", will still be available in the network tab for a browser check result.
Our provider has informed us that the incident is resolved
Our provider has informed us that a fix was in place and the issue is now being monitored
We traced the problem to our authentication provider. The issue is currently only affecting our webapp. We are reaching out to them.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
There was a spike in errors at our system. We are investigating the root cause.
Checks are now running normally and our parter at Vercel resolved the incident.
We're still seeing issues with our partner Vercel and checks running through the integration are affected.
Checks triggered with our Vercel integration are running again without issues. We're actively monitoring the health of our systems.
Our partner at Vercel is having issues with dashboard and builds, checks triggered with our Vercel integration could be failing.

incidents.name: Minor disruption to high frequency checks scheduling

incident_updates.body: Due to an increased load on our database, our check results processing pipeline got temporarily congested. Check results appeared with a delay in our webapp and API. Some checks with scheduling intervals of 1 minute and shorter, skipped a few beats between 16:30 and 17:15 UTC. We have successfully reduced the load on our DB, and restored the normal operation of our system.

incidents.name: Checkly must undergo critical database maintenance

incident_updates.body: We have finished the upgrade successfully with very minimal data loss. Should you have been affected, support will reach out to you shortly.
All services are working as expected. We are making sure there was no data loss.
The upgrade is complete. We are continuing to monitor for potential issues.

Checkly engineers will perform a critical database upgrade in a few moments. We worked very hard to make sure this will cause minimal to no data loss or downtime but would like to inform our customers to be extra transparent. If you experience any unexpected behavior, please reach out to support.
The underlying issue in our cloud provider has been resolved, and checks are running normally.
We are currently investigating an increased error rate in our check scheduler. The impact appears to be limited, and the majority check runs are executing without issues.
We see full recovery on all of our services and are setting this incident as resolved.
We are currently having connectivity issues with our database provider. We are investigating the issues and trying to resolve the issue as soon as possible.

This incident was caused by a database migration causing a downtime in our scheduler between 12:13 UTC and 12:38 UTC.

We had to restart some of our internal tools and checks scheduling has been functioning as normal since then.

The fix is successfuly working and all checks should run as normally scheduled again now.

incidents.name: Signing up a new account results in a login loop

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved and new users can now signup as expected.
We've deployed a fix and we're monitoring it for the next 10 minutes.
We've identifed the source of this issue and we're deploying a fix.
We are currently investigating this issue.

We were not able to connect to our primary database between 16:19 and 16:50 UTC today. This has been caused by an incident within our upstream provider.   
  
During the time of this incident all components of our application were unavailable. Some checks with intervals less than 30 minutes were not processed during this incident. The remaining checks were also not processed during the database outage, but have picked up by our scheduler afterwards with a delay.  

We are continuing to investigate the root cause with our upstream provider, and analysing solutions how to increase the availability of our primary datastore.

For approximately two minutes, from 18:13 to 18:15 UTC,  performance of the Checkly platform was degraded. During this time, check results were not stored and edits to checks failed.

This issue was triggered by maintenance on our database. To avoid similar issues in the future, our roadmap has plans to make our database more highly available.

incidents.name: Checks not running for Vercel deployments

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved. Vercel deployments with Checkly checks created during the incident, between 10:56 and 13:48 UTC Today, will be marked as "failing" in the Vercel UI, and the checks as "stale". New deployments are working as expected.
A fix has been implemented on the Vercel side and Checks for new deployments are running now. We are continuing to monitor the health of our systems
Our partners at Vercel have identified a recent change that is behind this incident. They are working actively on fixing the relevant code.
Checks for Vercel deployments are not executed since ~11:00 am UTC Today. We're working together with our partners at Vercel to pinpoint the issue.
The aforementioned fix seems to have successfully alleviated the issue. If you have any questions or are still having problems with deployments, don't hesitate to reach out to us!
We've rolled out a fix together with our partner. Deployments should now be running as usual.
We've identified the issue and are working with our partner to roll out a fix.

Our check scheduler had a disruption from 12:18 to 13:14 (GMT+1:00). This only affected checks inside groups, which may not have been scheduled during this time.

We have remediated the issue already and will publish a more detailed post-mortem soon.

incidents.name: Elevated response times in our Web Application and API

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved. We have temporarily disabled the "GET /v1/check-results/:checkId" endpoint, which was responsible for triggering the incident.

We have identified increased traffic to one of our public API endpoints. This has led to database connection saturation. We have temporarily disabled the offending endpoint. Currently, our API is available again. We are monitoring the health of our systems.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are currently investigating this issue.

incidents.name: API checks with POST and Form Body not sending correct content-type by default

incident_updates.body: A deploy caused a regression for API checks with POST requests and the form body type. We skipped setting the application/x-www-form-urlencoded content-type thus causing an error. A fix was deployed at 1pm by our engineers.
A database migration caused a 3 minute downtime with check scheduling. This was not planned and addressed immediately by our engineers.

On 10.11.21, for approximately 12 hours, a set of AWS development environment keys were accessible to the public. Upon initial inspection we did not find any signs of intrusion or vandalism. However, we take potential security issues like this extremely seriously and decided out of an abundance of caution to completely delete all resources in the AWS dev account.

We proceeded to use this opportunity to mitigate similar risks in the future by splitting this account into separate "dev" and "staging" accounts and recreated all resources separately.

This incident did not affect our production environment and no customer information was at risk due to this only affecting the internal development environment.
We have detected the source of the issue and released a fix. It was due to a dependency bug that was deployed recently
We are continuing to investigate this issue.

We had a hick up with our API instances. We scaled them up and can see that the issue related to memory usage is gone.
